009package com.weather.sdk.exception;
010
011/**
012 * The base exception class for all weather SDK related errors.
013 *
014 * <p>This is the root exception for the Weather SDK exception hierarchy. All other weather-specific
015 * exceptions extend from this class, providing a common base for catch-all exception handling while
016 * still allowing for specific exception handling through the more specialized subclasses.
017 *
018 * <h2>Exception Hierarchy</h2>
019 *
020 * <p>The Weather SDK uses a comprehensive exception hierarchy for clear error handling:
021 *
022 * <ul>
023 *   <li><strong>WeatherSDKException</strong> - Base class for all SDK errors
024 *   <li><strong>ApiKeyException</strong> - API key related issues (invalid, missing, etc.)
025 *   <li><strong>CityNotFoundException</strong> - City not found in OpenWeatherAPI
026 *   <li><strong>RateLimitException</strong> - API rate limit exceeded
027 *   <li><strong>NetworkException</strong> - Network connectivity or HTTP errors
028 *   <li><strong>CacheException</strong> - Cache operation failures
029 *   <li><strong>ConfigurationException</strong> - Invalid configuration parameters
030 * </ul>
031 *
032 * <h2>Error Codes</h2>
033 *
034 * <p>Each exception type provides a standardized error code that can be used for:
035 *
036 * <ul>
037 *   <li>Programmatic error handling and routing
038 *   <li>Logging and monitoring systems
039 *   <li>User-facing error messages
040 *   <li>Analytics and error tracking
041 * </ul>
042 *
043 * <h2>Usage Examples</h2>
044 *
045 * <h3>Catch Specific Exceptions</h3>
046 *
047 * <pre>
048 * try {
049 *   WeatherData weather = sdk.getWeather("London");
050 * } catch (CityNotFoundException e) {
051 *   logger.warn("City not found: {}", e.getMessage());
052 *   // Handle city not found specifically
053 * } catch (ApiKeyException e) {
054 *   logger.error("Invalid API key: {}", e.getMessage());
055 *   // Handle API key issues
056 * } catch (RateLimitException e) {
057 *   logger.warn("Rate limit exceeded: {}", e.getMessage());
058 *   // Implement backoff strategy
059 * }
060 * </pre>
061 *
062 * <h3>Catch All SDK Exceptions</h3>
063 *
064 * <pre>
065 * try {
066 *   WeatherData weather = sdk.getWeather("Paris");
067 * } catch (WeatherSDKException e) {
068 *   logger.error("Weather SDK error ({}): {}", e.getErrorCode(), e.getMessage());
069 *   // Handle any weather-related error
070 * }
071 * </pre>
072 *
073 * <h3>Error Code Usage</h3>
074 *
075 * <pre>
076 * // Programmatic error handling based on error codes
077 * try {
078 *   WeatherData weather = sdk.getWeather("Berlin");
079 * } catch (WeatherSDKException e) {
080 *   switch (e.getErrorCode()) {
081 *     case INVALID_API_KEY:
082 *       // Trigger API key rotation
083 *       rotateApiKey();
084 *       break;
085 *     case RATE_LIMIT_EXCEEDED:
086 *       // Implement exponential backoff
087 *       backoffAndRetry();
088 *       break;
089 *     case CITY_NOT_FOUND:
090 *       // Suggest alternative city names
091 *       suggestSimilarCities();
092 *       break;
093 *     default:
094 *       // Handle unknown errors
095 *       handleUnknownError(e);
096 *   }
097 * }
098 * </pre>
099 *
100 * @since 1.0.0
101 * @see com.weather.sdk.exception.ApiKeyException
102 * @see com.weather.sdk.exception.CityNotFoundException
103 * @see com.weather.sdk.exception.RateLimitException
104 * @see com.weather.sdk.exception.NetworkException
105 * @see com.weather.sdk.exception.CacheException
106 * @see com.weather.sdk.exception.ConfigurationException
107 */
108public abstract class WeatherSDKException extends Exception {
109
110  /** Serial version UID for serialization compatibility. */
111  private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
112
113  /** The error code for this exception type. This constant should be overridden by subclasses. */
114  public static final String WEATHER_SDK_ERROR = "WEATHER_SDK_ERROR";
115
116  /** The error code associated with this exception. */
117  private final String errorCode;
118
119  /**
120   * Constructs a new WeatherSDKException with the specified error code and message.
121   *
122   * @param errorCode the error code for this exception. Must not be null or empty.
123   * @param message the detail message. Must not be null.
124   * @throws NullPointerException if errorCode or message is null
125   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if errorCode is empty
126   */
127  @SuppressWarnings("CT_CONSTRUCTOR_THROW")
128  protected WeatherSDKException(final String errorCode, final String message) {
129    super(message);
130    this.errorCode = validateErrorCode(errorCode);
131  }
132
133  /**
134   * Creates a new WeatherSDKException with the specified error code and message.
135   *
136   * @param errorCode the error code for this exception. Must not be null or empty.
137   * @param message the detail message. Must not be null.
138   * @return a new WeatherSDKException instance
139   * @throws NullPointerException if errorCode or message is null
140   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if errorCode is empty
141   */
142  public static WeatherSDKException create(final String errorCode, final String message) {
143    return new WeatherSDKException(errorCode, message) {};
144  }
145
146  /**
147   * Constructs a new WeatherSDKException with the specified error code, message, and cause.
148   *
149   * @param errorCode the error code for this exception. Must not be null or empty.
150   * @param message the detail message. Must not be null.
151   * @param cause the underlying cause. May be null.
152   * @throws NullPointerException if errorCode or message is null
153   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if errorCode is empty
154   */
155  @SuppressWarnings("CT_CONSTRUCTOR_THROW")
156  protected WeatherSDKException(
157      final String errorCode, final String message, final Throwable cause) {
158    super(message, cause);
159    this.errorCode = validateErrorCode(errorCode);
160  }
161
162  /**
163   * Returns the error code associated with this exception.
164   *
165   * <p>Error codes are standardized strings that identify the type of error that occurred. They can
166   * be used for programmatic error handling, logging, and monitoring.
167   *
168   * @return the error code. Never returns null or empty.
169   */
170  public String getErrorCode() {
171    return errorCode;
172  }
173
174  /**
175   * Returns a formatted string containing both the error code and message.
176   *
177   * <p>This is useful for logging and error reporting where both pieces of information are needed.
178   *
179   * @return a formatted error string in the format "ERROR_CODE: message"
180   */
181  public String getFormattedMessage() {
182    return String.format("%s: %s", errorCode, getMessage());
183  }
184
185  /**
186   * Returns a brief description of this exception type.
187   *
188   * <p>Subclasses should override this method to provide a more specific description of the
189   * exception type.
190   *
191   * @return a brief description of this exception
192   */
193  public String getExceptionType() {
194    return "Weather SDK Error";
195  }
196
197  /**
198   * Validates that the error code is not null or empty.
199   *
200   * @param errorCode the error code to validate
201   * @return the validated error code
202   * @throws NullPointerException if errorCode is null
203   * @throws IllegalArgumentException if errorCode is empty
204   */
205  private static String validateErrorCode(final String errorCode) {
206    if (errorCode == null) {
207      throw new IllegalArgumentException("Error code must not be null");
208    }
209    final String trimmed = errorCode.trim();
210    if (trimmed.isEmpty()) {
211      throw new IllegalArgumentException("Error code must not be empty");
212    }
213    return trimmed;
214  }
215
216  @Override
217  public String toString() {
218    return String.format("%s[%s]: %s", getClass().getSimpleName(), errorCode, getMessage());
219  }
220}
